description: From Middle English bracer, from Old French braceure; equivalent to brace +â€Ž -er.

entries.meaning: That which braces, binds, or makes firm; a band or bandage.

examples: Country air in the fields, or in gardens, when breathed at proper hours, is an excellent bracer of the nerves, and a sure brightener of the complexion.

entries.meaning: (archery) A covering to protect the arm of the bowman from the vibration of the string.
examples: To prevent the bow string from hanging on the left arm, it is covered with a piece of smooth leather, fastened on the outside of the arm, this is called a bracer.

entries.meaning: Armor for the forearm; a brassard.
A medicine, as an astringent or a tonic, which gives tension or tone to any part of the body.
